list.title: Question 1
list.content: The organisms in the table below all share a common ancestor. OrganismVertebraeTwo pairs of limbsSweat GlandsTroutPresentAbsentAbsentBlack bearPresentPresentAbsentHumanPresentPresentPresent - - Use the data in the table to draw a cladogram. [2] - State the source of variation which allowed organisms in the cladogram to diverge into different species [1] - In cladistics, state the name used to describe a group of organisms which have all evolved from a common ancestor. [1]
list.markScheme: - - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ a node for a common ancestor [1] $\ce{ -> }$ organisms in the correct order (trout, black bear, human) [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/44ad43f9-26fa-4810-80af-e45631739993/images/a702b776-b79e-4f55-8a6c-2b7ca3b3f99f/273ai.png) Only names of organisms expected, features added just for explanation. - $\ce{ -> }$ mutations [1] [1 mark maximum] - $\ce{ -> }$ clade [1] [1 mark maximum]

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Which of the following statements is the correct definition of evolution?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Heritable characteristics of a species change over time.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Organisms are reproductively isolated.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Learned behaviours change over time.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Organisms are bred for desired characteristics.
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Evolution is the change in the characteristics of a population over time; these characteristics can be passed from one generation to another (Choice A). Choice B is incorrect as it describes when organisms are reproductively isolated, which is a mechanism that may lead to evolution in a population. Choice C is incorrect because it refers to learned behaviours which are learned within an organismâ€™s lifetime and are not genetically inherited. Choice D is incorrect as it refers to selective breeding.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
What evidence can be, and has been used, to determine the members of the same clade?


- I.	$\hspace{1em}$ Base sequence of genes
- II.	$\hspace{.7em}$ Amino acid sequence of proteins
- III.	$\hspace{.4em}$ Physical appearance of organisms




- A.	$\hspace{1em}$ II only
- B.	$\hspace{1em}$ I and II
- C.	$\hspace{1em}$ II and III
- D.	$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct.
The DNA sequence (Statement I) and amino acid sequence (Statement II) are the usual, present way of determining members of the same clade, however, physical appearance (Statement III) was previously, but is now rarely, used.

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
In cladistics, which is the correct definition of a clade?



- A.	$\hspace{1em}$ A group of organisms with the same DNA sequence
- B.	$\hspace{1em}$ A group of organisms that share a common ancestor
- C.	$\hspace{1em}$ A group of organisms with different DNA sequences
- D.	$\hspace{1em}$ A group of organisms that do not share a common ancestor
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is the correct definition for a clade, a group of organisms that share a common ancestor. Choice A and C are incorrect as they do not feature the idea of a common ancestor. Choice D is incorrect because organisms within a clade do share a common ancestor.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
According to natural classification, organisms in the same group had what in common?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Morphology
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	Anatomical characteristic
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	Modes of nutrition
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	Common ancestry
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because organisms placed in the same group share common ancestry. Choice A and Choice B are incorrect because morphology and anatomical characteristics are used to describe the structures of organisms which are used to primarily group them together. Choice C is incorrect because modes of nutrition are used to describe organisms but not to classify organisms.

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
To which domain do organisms with membrane-enclosed organelles belong to?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Eukaryota
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	Archaea
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	Eubacteria
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	Prokaryotes
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because Eukaryota are the only group with nuclei and membrane-bound organelles. Choice B and choice C are incorrect because organisms in these two domains (Archaea and Eubacteria) do not have membrane-enclosed organelles. Choice D is incorrect because prokaryotes are not the name of a domain.

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Which technique estimates the divergence time between species based on genetic differences?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Radioactive dating
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Molecular clock dating
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Comparative anatomy
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Studying fossil layers
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Molecular clock dating uses the genetic differences between species to estimate their times of divergence. This method relies on the assumption that mutations accumulate at a relatively constant rate over time. By comparing the DNA sequences of different organisms, scientists can estimate how long ago their last common ancestor lived. Choice B is, therefore, correct.
Radioactive dating is a method used to date rocks and other materials based on the known decay rates of radioactive isotopes. Choice A is, therefore, not correct.
Comparative anatomy involves comparing the structures of different organisms to understand their evolutionary relationships. While it can provide evidence of common ancestry and evolutionary trends, it does not offer a precise method for estimating the time of divergence between species based on genetic differences. Choice C is, therefore, not correct.
Studying the distribution of fossils within sedimentary rock layers establishes relative ages and the chronological order of geological and evolutionary events. Whilst it is essential for constructing the timeline of life on Earth, it does not use genetic differences to estimate divergence times between species. Choice D is, therefore, not correct.

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Which taxonomic group of organisms represents a domain?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Eukaryota
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Plantae
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Protoctista
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Animalia
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Eukaryota is one of only three domains - the other two being Archaea and Eubacteria.
Choice B (Plantae) is one of the five kingdoms, not a domain. Choice C (Protoctista) and  Choice D (Animalia) are also kingdoms.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Which of the following represents the correct order for the traditional taxonomic hierarchy?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Class $\rightarrow$ Order	$\rightarrow$ Family
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Phylum $\rightarrow$ Order $\rightarrow$ Class
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Order $\rightarrow$ Genus	$\rightarrow$ Family
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Kingdom	$\rightarrow$ Order	$\rightarrow$ Phylum
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because the traditional hierarchy of taxa is a domain, kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus, so class $\rightarrow$ order $\rightarrow$ family is in the correct order. Choice B is incorrect because the class is above order. Choice C is incorrect because the family is above genus. Choice D is incorrect because the phylum is above order.

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
In a cladogram, what is represented by a node?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ A new trait that is shared by two organisms
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ The most recent common ancestor between species
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ A group of organisms with a common ancestor
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ The most genetically distant organisms
list.markScheme:
B
$\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: 
Nodes on a cladogram are a splitting point that represent the most recent ancestor between species; Choice B is correct.
A node does not represent a new trait shared by two organisms; Choice A is incorrect. A group of organisms with a common ancestor is a clade, not a node; Choice C  is incorrect. The most genetically distant organism on a cladogram is an outgroup, not a node; Choice D  is incorrect.

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
Which arrow correctly identifies a node in the cladogram?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/69c93911-093d-43fa-b75c-1769ca9016d1/images/c793b196-2c02-4fd1-91e0-0de4b74073d4/BI0266%20primate%20cladogram%20i.png)


[Adapted from: Source Bockman, P. (2011, October 3). File: Primate cladogram.jpg. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 14, 2022, from https:// commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Primate_cladogram.jpg CC-BY-SA-3.0]
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
A node is the point where species diverge. Choice D is correct. Choices A and B are incorrect as they point to the middle of the line, so they do not represent divergence. Choice C is incorrect as it points to a species.

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
According to the cladogram, which two primates are the most closely related?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/008ac188-a233-4bb5-b8bb-1f6a59da105e/images/1afb59aa-b10a-4467-b0d5-c7f223838826/BI0263.png)


[Adapted from: Source Bockman, P. (2011, October 3). File: Primate cladogram.jpg. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 14, 2022, from https:// commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Primate_cladogram.jpg CC-BY-SA-3.0]



- A.	$\hspace{1em}$ New world monkeys and old world monkeys
- B.	$\hspace{1em}$ Lorises and lemurs
- C.	$\hspace{1em}$ Lemurs and humans
- D.	$\hspace{1em}$ Apes and humans
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Humans and apes (Choice D) are the most closely related because they shared a common ancestor more recently than the other primates, such as new world and old world monkeys (Choice A), Lorises and Lemurs (Choice B) and Lemurs and Humans (Choice C).

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
The diagram below represents the three domains of life.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/292dca29-d444-488e-b4ca-9141aee0f532/images/921a7728-af80-441f-a1f0-9779a836ac28/BI0251ii.png)


[ Â© Revision Village 2022]

Which row has the correct names for the domains?

Domain 1Domain 2Domain 3$\hspace{1em}$A.$\hspace{1em}$ArchaeaProkaryotesEukaryote$\hspace{1em}$B.$\hspace{1em}$ProtistaProkaryotaEukaryota$\hspace{1em}$C.$\hspace{1em}$ProtistaEubacteriaEukaryota$\hspace{1em}$D.$\hspace{1em}$EubacteriaArchaeaEukaryota
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because the three domains of organisms are Archaea, Eubacteria and Eukaryota. Choice A is incorrect because prokaryote is not the name of one of the domains. Choice B is incorrect because Protista and prokaryota are not the names of domains. Choice C is incorrect because Protista is not one of the domains.

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
Early cladograms were constructed by comparing structures of organisms. The cladogram on the left is based on structure and the cladogram on the right is based on comparing the DNA sequence of a particular gene.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/71a6aa14-4f15-478b-a24a-ca99ed0fd98f/images/cbe839a7-5b86-466c-bb39-f4cbda23ccd1/BI0551.png)

[Source: Left: Adapted from Milinkovitch, M., Thewissen, J. (1997). Even-toed fingerprints on whale ancestry. Nature 388, (622â€“623).  Retrieved January 4, 2023, from https://doi.org/10.1038/41650. Copyright under open access; Right: Adapted from Masato Nikaido, Alejandro P. Rooney, Norihiro Okada. (1999, August 31). Phylogenetic relationships among cetartiodactyls based on insertions of short and long interpersed elements: Hippopotamuses are the closest extant relatives of whales. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Retrieved January 4, 2023, from https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.96.18.10261.  Copyright-free.]

What is the reason that the cladogram based on the DNA sequences is a more reliable representation of the sequence of divergence among clades than the cladogram based on structures?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Structures are not inherited when species diverge.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ DNA does not change over time while structures can change over time.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Similar structures can be coded for by different genes in genetically distant organisms.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ There are many different structures that are coded for by the same DNA sequence.
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Morphological traits, or structures, are useful for creating cladograms. However, cladograms created by comparing such traits may be inaccurate because distantly related organisms can have structures that appear similar but have different genetic bases. The appearance of similar structures with a different evolutionary basis is not evidence of relatedness, but rather is evidence of convergent evolution. So, one reason the cladogram based on the DNA sequences is more reliable than the cladogram based on structures is that similar structures can be coded for by different genes in genetically distant organisms.
Choice A is incorrect because structures are inherited when species diverge, and the inheritance of structures is beneficial for constructing cladograms.  This is because shared structures are sometimes, but not always, evidence of genetic relatedness.
Choice B is incorrect because DNA does change over time. Scientists look at sequences of changes in DNA to determine evolutionary relatedness.
Choice D is incorrect because different structures are generally coded for by different DNA sequences.

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
What information can be deduced from the cladogram?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a7b55663-83dc-4b1c-8dc9-a1a4836ae09c/images/d887ade3-cdd4-4ad6-89ee-2d5616c78b8b/cladogram%20of%20primates%20i.png)

[Adapted from: Source Bockman, P. (2011, October 3). File: Primate cladogram.jpg. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 14, 2022, from https:// commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Primate_cladogram.jpg CC-BY-SA-3.0]



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Lorises and Tarsiers share a common ancestor.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Old world monkeys and New world monkeys have the same DNA sequences.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Human and Lemur species are the same age.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Tarsiers and Lemurs do not share a common ancestor.
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
All organisms on the same cladogram share a common ancestor. Choice A is correct. Choice B is incorrect as old world and new world monkeys have evolutionarily split on the cladogram, so there are differences in their DNA sequence. Choice C is incorrect as this cladogram does not show the age of the species. Choice D is incorrect because lemurs and tarsiers are on the same cladogram so they do share the same ancestor.

list.title: Question 16
list.content: The cladogram below shows three possible evolutionary origins of the platypus (Platypus X, Y, and Z), an egg-laying mammal with webbed feet. The italicised taxa are extinct. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b1d5b447-bd27-4715-ae01-364bf736d736/images/2b9787f4-b693-44f9-8732-f9b721309317/bi0565.png) [Sources: adapted from Celik, M.A. and Phillips, M.J. (2020). Conflict Resolution for Mesozoic Mammals: Reconciling Phylogenetic Incongruence Among Anatomical Regions. Front. Genet. 11:0651. Retrieved January 4, 2023 from https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32774343/. Copyright under CC BY 4.0] - - State the taxa most closely related to marsupials. [1] - Based on the taxa shown in the cladogram, deduce one reason for the difficulty in identifying the true divergence of the platypus.[1] - - The cladogram shown is based on morphological traits. Describe one other type of evidence that can be used to deduce evolutionary relationships. [2] - Suggest one type of morphological evidence that could be used to provide support for Platypus Z over Platypus X as the origin of the platypus. [1] - Taxonomists classify organisms according to their evolutionary origins using a hierarchical classification system. Outline the principal taxonomic ranks in the modern classification system. [2]
list.markScheme: - - $\ce{->}$ placental mammals [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Placental mammals ($\checkmark$) are most closely related to marsupials. They are both members of Theria. - Any one of the following: $\ce{->}$ most species are extinct [1] $\ce{->}$ must rely on fossil evidence [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Most of the species in the cladogram are extinct ($\checkmark$), so scientists must rely on fossils ($\checkmark$) of these organisms to identify relatedness and determine the divergence of the platypus. - - Any two of the following: $\ce{->}$ DNA sequence OR gene sequences OR amino acid sequences OR protein sequences [1] $\ce{->}$ compare sequences for shared gene OR protein in different species [1] $\ce{->}$ number of differences in sequences indicates degree of relatedness OR the more differences there are between species the more distantly related they are [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Scientists can use DNA sequences ($\checkmark$) to determine evolutionary relationships. For example, scientists might compare the nucleotide sequence of a shared gene across species ($\checkmark$). By comparing the sequences of nucleotides in the same gene, scientists can infer the order in which the changes most likely occurred. This allows them to determine the most likely divergence order ($\checkmark$) among the organisms. - Any one of the following: $\ce{->}$ identification OR comparison of homologous structures [1] $\ce{->}$ identification of vestigial structures [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Scientists could identify and compare homologous structures ($\checkmark$) in the platypus to those of other mammals. For example, if the webbed feet of the platypus are more like the feet of marsupials than the feet of ancestral species like Docodonta, the platypus may be more closely related to Theria than it is to Docodonta. OR Alternative answer Scientists could identify vestigial structures ($\checkmark$) in the platypus and other mammals. For example, if the platypus and marsupials have similar vestigial structures that are also similar to functional structures that were present in earlier groups of mammals, the platypus likely emerged after Docodonta in the evolution of mammals. - Any two of the following: $\ce{->}$ domain is the largest rank [1] $\ce{->}$ the three domains are Archaea, Eubacteria, and Eukarya [1] $\ce{->}$ domain Eukarya is split into kingdoms [1] $\ce{->}$ from largest to smallest, kingdoms are divided into phyla OR phylum, classes, orders, families, genera OR genuses, and species [1] $\ce{->}$ species are sometimes divided into subspecies [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The largest rank in the classification system is the domain ($\checkmark$). There are three domains â€“ Archaea, Eubacteria, and Eukarya ($\checkmark$). The domain Eukarya is divided into 4 kingdoms ($\checkmark$) â€“ Protista, Fungi, Plantae, and Animalia. Each kingdom is further divided, from largest to smallest into phyla, class, order, family, genus, and species ($\checkmark$).

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
The image shows the skulls of a gorilla, chimpanzee, and human. What conclusion can be drawn from the anatomies of the skulls?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dae42746-c318-47a8-bb28-40949593158e/images/1dc8d91c-26ff-4b43-954b-8b30cb9b0c03/BI1522%20fig1.png)


[Source: Adapted from Zhang, K. (2015, May 1). Wikimedia Commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved February 29, 2024.https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: The_Skulls_of_the_gorilla,chimpanzee_and_humans_-_Kaiwei_Zhang.jpg. Copyright free]



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Gorillas and chimpanzees are more closely related to each other than they are to humans
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Humans are more intelligent than chimpanzees and gorillas
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Gorillas, chimpanzees and humans share a recent common ancestor
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Chimpanzees and gorillas have a diploid chromosome number of 48, whereas humans have a diploid chromosome number of 46
list.markScheme:
C
$\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: 
The similar anatomies of the gorilla, chimpanzee and human skull suggest they have a common ancestor; Choice C  is correct.
Choice A  is incorrect, as similar anatomy is not enough to say that gorillas and chimpanzees are more closely related to each other than humans due to convergent evolution. Choice B is incorrect, as skull size is not necessarily correlated to intelligence. Choice D  is incorrect as skull size and shape do not provide any information on chromosome number.

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
Which of the following is not evidence for organisms being in the same clade?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Chimpanzees (P. troglodytes) share 99% of their DNA with humans (H. sapiens).
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ African elephants (L. africana) and manatees share a common ancestor (T. manatus).
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Bonobo  (P. paniscus) and humans (H. sapiens) both choose to play with gender specific toys.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ E. coli have a 95% similarity amino acid sequence to S. enterica.
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Two organisms having similar behaviour is not evidence that they belong in the same clade so Choice C is correct. A clade is a group of organisms that have evolved from a common ancestor, and is usually determined by similarity in amino acid and DNA sequences, therefore Choices A, B and D could be used as evidence for organisms to be in the same clad and are thus incorrect for this question.

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
What is the relationship between the number of differences in DNA base sequences and time since divergence from a common ancestor?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ The lower the number of differences, the more recently organisms diverged from each other.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ The number of differences is equal to the number of years since the organisms diverged.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ The higher the number of differences, the more recently organisms diverged from each other.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ There is no relationship between the number of differences in DNA base sequences and time since divergence.
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The number of sequence differences acts as a molecular clock, so the lower the number of differences accumulated in the DNA base sequence, the more closely related and more recently the organisms diverged from each other. Choice A is correct. Choice B is incorrect because the number of differences is not an exact measurement of time. Choice C is incorrect as itâ€™s the opposite of Choice A. Choice D is incorrect as there is a relationship.

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
The table shows the number of differences in amino acid sequences for the Insulin-A protein, between pigs and other organisms.
$\hspace{3em}$ Organism $\hspace{3em}$Number of differences in amino acid sequence for Insulin-AHuman2Cow5Giraffe50Goat4Warthog1Chimpanzee10Flamingo25

Which organism would be furthest from pigs in a cladogram?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Warthogs because they have the least number of differences
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Giraffes because they have the largest number of differences
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Humans because they are most different physically
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Flamingoes because they have a different number of limbs
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Organisms with the largest differences in the amino acid sequence are the most evolutionarily diverged, so would be the furthest apart. Choice B is correct. Choice A is incorrect as warthogs and pigs have the least number of differences so would be the closest organisms on a cladogram. Choices C and D are incorrect because cladograms are not based on physical appearance.

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
The cyanobacteria Leptolyngbya nigrescens  has recently been reclassified as Phormidesmis nigrescens. What is a  possible reason for this?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Observation of similar sensitivities to light between bacteria in the Phormidesmis genus and the newly classified Phormidesmis nigrescens
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Discovery of structural similarities of cyanobacteria to other bacteria in the Leptolyngbya genus
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Discovery of similarities in ribosomal RNA sequences between Phormidesmis nigrescens and other bacteria in the Phormidesmis genus
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ New evidence that Phormidesmis nigrescens  share a common ancestor with other cyanobacteria in the Leptolyngbya genus
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Similarities between ribosomal RNA sequences between Phormidesmis nigrescens  and other bacteria in the Phormidesmis genus indicates that they are likely to share a common ancestor, belong in the same genus and therefore should be reclassified. Choice C is correct.
Similarities in behaviour do not indicate that Phormidesmis nigrescens  share a common ancestor with other bacteria in the Phormidesmis genus; Choice A  is incorrect. To be reclassified, the Phormidesmis nigrescens should be more similar to bacteria in the Phormidesmis genus than the Leptolyngbya genus, also structural similarities are not grounds for reclassification; Choice B is incorrect. To be reclassified, the Phormidesmis nigrescens should share a common ancestor with cyanobacteria in the Phormidesmis genus rather than the Leptolyngbya genus; Choice D  is incorrect.

list.title: Question 22
list.content: The image shows a cladogram for several species of hamster. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/47f20b44-acd8-4729-8737-b858aa3d4375/images/f8f32c6b-0ecc-4be9-ac60-535e09501347/BI1375.png) [Source: Adapted from Michaplot. (2012, January 4). File: PhodopusCladogram.jpg. Wikipedia. Retrieved December 04, 2023 from URL https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File.jpg. Copyright under CC BY 3.0] - State what is represented by the letter X. [1] - Other than their positions on the cladogram, explain what information indicates that Phodopus campbelli and Phodopus sungorus are closely related. [1] - Modern hamsters have small, furry ears. The common ancestor of the hamsters in the cladogram has been hypothesised to have large, furry ears. Suggest how natural selection explains these changes. [3]
list.markScheme: - Any one of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ node [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the last common ancestor of Phodopus campbelli AND Phodopus sungorus [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Letter X represents a node ($\checkmark$). - Any one of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ they are from the same genus OR in the Phodopus genus [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: They are in the same genus ($\checkmark$). - Any fthree of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ natural selection is the process by which species change over time in response to changes in the environment OR competition between organisms in order for species to survive [1] $\ce{ -> }$ random mutation resulted in new allele for smaller ears [1] $\ce{ -> }$ increases genetic variation OR diversity within the population [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mutation OR new allele OR allele for smaller ears proved beneficial OR led to greater chance of survival [1] $\ce{ -> }$ increased reproductive success OR more chance of having offspring OR having more offspring [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the offspring inherited the allele for smaller ears OR beneficial alleles passed onto next generation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ over many generations the allele for shorter ears increased in frequency in the population OR small-eared hamsters increased in number in the population [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Many years ago, random mutations occurred in some hamsters that gave them new alleles for smaller ears ($\checkmark$), the allele for smaller ears gave those hamsters a survival advantage ($\checkmark$). These hamsters were more likely to have offspring ($\checkmark$), and the beneficial allele for small ears was passed onto the offspring ($\checkmark$). Over many generations, there was an increase in the number of hamsters with smaller ears and a decrease in the number of hamsters with larger ears ($\checkmark$).

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
The following image shows a member of the Scrophulariaceae (figwort) family drawn in 1774. Although this family was once among the largest groups of flowering plants, it has since been reclassified and is now less than half of its former size. Which of the following explains why reclassification of taxonomic groups may be required?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7c908cc5-d161-4aae-aebd-4022e07a9452/images/faca6029-51b6-4e7b-9dc9-1f94775fc7d7/BI1390.png)


[Source: Bouchard, M. (1774). Figwort (Scrophularia sp): flowering stem with separate flower. Look and Learn. Retrieved December 30, 2023, from https://www.lookandlearn.com/history-images/YW042762VEL/Figwort-Scrophularia-sp-flowering-stem-with-separate-flower. Copyright BY CC 4.0]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Genomic sequencing
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Improvements in dichotomous keys
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Genetically modified species
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Discovery of new species
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
When the taxonomic system was developed, species were largely classified according to physical similarities. With the discovery of DNA and gene sequencing techniques, it became possible to compare the genomes of organisms. Genomic data allows the evolutionary relationships between organisms to be determined much more accurately and thus can lead to the reclassification of some taxa. Choice A is correct.
Choice B is incorrect because dichotomous keys are used to identify organisms based on observable characteristics, not for reclassifying taxonomic groups. Choice C is incorrect because genetic modification is when the genetic material of an organism has been altered through human intervention, however, this does not lead to the reclassification of species. Choice D is incorrect since the discovery of a new species should not affect previously classified organisms, especially if genome sequencing is used as the primary means of classification.

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
Which of the following would not be a reason for reclassification?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Discovery of a new species
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Evidence for a common ancestor
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Evidence of similar bone structures
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Observation of different behaviours
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because behaviours do not indicate common ancestry. Choice B is incorrect because natural classification is based on common ancestry so evidence for a common ancestor can lead to reclassification. Choice A is incorrect because the discovery of a new species may provide evidence of a common ancestor and lead to reclassification. Choice C is incorrect because evidence of similar bone structures may be part of the evidence for a common ancestor and lead to an organism being reclassified.

list.title: Question 25
list.content: - Outline how mitochondrial DNA can be used to construct a cladogram. [4] - Explain why organisms classified in the past may be reclassified. [4] - Compare and contrast cladograms made using molecular evidence and structural evidence. [7]
list.markScheme: - Any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondrial DNA from different organisms can be sequenced [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mutations occur at a roughly constant rate OR can act as a molecular clock [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the lower the number of differences in the base sequence between organisms, the more closely related the organisms are [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the number of differences in the base sequence can be used to determine how long ago species diverged from a common ancestor [1] $\ce{ -> }$ which can be used to deduce where the nodes are on cladograms [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Sections of mitochondrial DNA from different organisms can be sequenced ($\checkmark$), which allows scientists to observe differences in the base sequence. The lower the number of differences in the base sequence between organisms, the more closely related the organisms are ($\checkmark$). The number of differences in the sequence of mitochondrial DNA can also be used to determine how long ago species diverged from a common ancestor ($\checkmark$), which can be used to deduce position of nodes on cladograms ($\checkmark$). - Any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ organisms (used to be) classified based on shared anatomical characteristics OR structures OR physical features [1] $\ce{ -> }$ shared anatomical characteristics OR structures OR physical features may be analogous OR not due to common ancestry [1] $\ce{ -> }$ analogous structures as a result of convergent evolution [1] $\ce{ -> }$ organisms (are now) classified using amino acid OR DNA sequences [1] $\ce{ -> }$ increased accuracy OR reliability of cladograms made using DNA OR amino acid sequences [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: In the past, organisms were classified based on shared physical features ($\checkmark$), however physical features could be analogous and therefore not the result of common ancestry ($\checkmark$). Cladograms which are constructed using DNA or amino acid sequences ($\checkmark$) are more reliable ($\checkmark$) and can highlight new evolutionary relationships which would lead to organisms potentially being reclassified. - Any seven of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH seek to demonstrate OR deduce evolutionary relationships [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH contain a root OR ancestor common to all organisms within the cladogram [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH contain nodes OR points at which species diverged from one another [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH contain clades OR an ancestor and all of its evolutionary descendants [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH can contain outgroups OR the most distantly related species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ species in BOTH may be reclassified (in response to new evidence) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ species organised based on anatomical structures OR physical characteristics WHEREAS species are organised based on amino acid OR DNA sequence [1] $\ce{ -> }$ in the past cladograms were constructed using similarities in physical features WHEREAS now DNA OR amino acid sequences are used [1] $\ce{ -> }$ molecular evidence OR DNA sequences OR amino sequences more reliable OR accurate than structural evidence OR physical characteristics [1] $\ce{ -> }$ analogous structures can be an issue in cladograms made using structural similarities BUT not in cladograms using molecular evidence OR DNA OR amino acid sequences [1] $\ce{ -> }$ cladograms made using structural evidence require less technology COMPARED to cladograms using molecular evidence OR DNA or amino acid sequences [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Cladograms which are made using structural evidence and those made using molecular evidence have several things in common, for example, both have features such as a root ($\checkmark$), nodes ($\checkmark$) and clades ($\checkmark$), they both also attempt to show evolutionary relationships between species ($\checkmark$). However there are some differences in these cladograms. In cladograms made using structural evidence, the physical characteristics of species are used to organise them into groups, but in cladograms using molecular evidence, scientists use the number of differences in the DNA or amino acid sequence ($\checkmark$), which is known to be the more reliable ($\checkmark$) method and is more commonly used now, compared to structural features being used more in the past ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

list.title: Question 26
list.content: - Explain four properties of water that make it important in supporting life on Earth. [4] - Describe the recent methods used to reclassify plant groups, such as the figwort family (Scrophulariaceae), based on cladistic evidence. [4] - Explain how the structure of synovial joints is adapted for movement and why this influences the range of motion. [7]
list.markScheme: - any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ solvent so enables reactions to occur OR transport of substances [1] $\ce{ -> }$ large latent heat of vaporisation OR A large amount of energy is needed to evaporate water so provides a cooling effect [1] $\ce{ -> }$ high specific heat capacity OR water absorbs OR retains heat without large changes in temperature, providing thermal stability in aquatic environments OR organisms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ cohesion OR hydrogen bonding between water molecules aids water transport in plants OR creates surface tension, enabling small organisms OR insects to move on water [1] $\ce{ -> }$ adhesion OR water molecules stick to other polar surfaces, supporting capillary action in plants [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ice floats OR ice is less dense than liquid water OR waterâ€™s density decreases as it cools below 4$\degree$C insulating aquatic ecosystems in cold climates OR helping aquatic life survive in cold conditions [1] $\ce{ -> }$ water is transparent, allowing light to penetrate for photosynthesis in aquatic plants OR algae OR enables visibility in aquatic environments [1] $\ce{ -> }$ provides buoyancy, enabling aquatic organisms to remain suspended OR supports the body structure of soft-bodied aquatic organisms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ amphoteric nature OR can act as both an acid and a base, maintaining pH balance in biological systems [1] $\ce{ -> }$ non-compressible helps maintain cell turgor OR structure of plant cells [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Water has a high specific heat capacity which allows it to absorb and retain heat, providing thermal stability for aquatic environments and living organisms ($\checkmark$). It is also a universal solvent due to its polarity, enabling it to dissolve ions and organic molecules for transport and biochemical reactions ($\checkmark$). The cohesion between water molecules supports the transport of water in plants through the xylem, while surface tension allows small organisms, like insects, to move on water ($\checkmark$). Ice is less dense than liquid water, which ensures it floats and insulates aquatic ecosystems in cold environments, protecting life below ($\checkmark$). - any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ early classification was based on morphology OR grouped plants based on visible traits [1] $\ce{ -> }$ early classification often led to misclassification due to convergent evolution [1] $\ce{ -> }$ recent cladistics relies on molecular data, OR DNA OR RNA nucleotide OR amino acid sequencing OR sequence comparisons [1] $\ce{ -> }$ molecular clock estimates divergence times OR DNA mutations occur at a relatively constant rate, allowing estimation of when species diverged from a common ancestor [1] $\ce{ -> }$ phylogenetic tree construction from genetic data [1] $\ce{ -> }$ common derived characteristics define clades [1] $\ce{ -> }$ number of differences in genetic sequences indicates evolutionary distance from a common ancestor [1] $\ce{ -> }$ use of outgroups to determine which traits are homologous OR ancestral OR which traits are analogous OR result from convergent evolution [1] $\ce{ -> }$ cladistics has led to reclassification of plant families OR figwort family OR Scrophulariaceae was reclassified after genetic analysis revealed it contained multiple unrelated lineages [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Early plant classification was based on morphology, grouping plants by visible traits such as leaf and flower structure ($\checkmark$). However, this often led to misclassification due to convergent evolution, where unrelated species developed similar features ($\checkmark$). Modern cladistics now relies on DNA sequencing to analyse genetic differences and determine evolutionary relationships ($\checkmark$). The molecular clock helps estimate divergence times, as mutations accumulate at a relatively constant rate ($\checkmark$). This has led to the reclassification of plant families, such as the figwort family (Scrophulariaceae), after genetic analysis revealed multiple unrelated lineages ($\checkmark$). - any seven of the following (must contain at least two from each section to gain full marks): how the structure of a synovial joint allows movement $\ce{ -> }$ joint cavity filled with synovial fluid, WHICH reduces friction OR allows smooth movement OR nourishes the cartilage OR lubricates the joint [1] $\ce{ -> }$ articulating surfaces of bones are covered by cartilage WHICH reduces friction OR cushions the joint OR prevents bone-to-bone contact [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ligaments provide stability by connecting bones AND preventing excessive or harmful movement [1] $\ce{ -> }$ synovial membrane produces synovial fluid [1] $\ce{ -> }$ capsule OR capsular ligament seals the joint AND provides additional stability while allowing movement [1] $\ce{ -> }$ bones provide a firm anchorage for muscles AND act as levers to amplify movement [1] $\ce{ -> }$ tendons attach muscles to bones, enabling movement when muscles contract [1] factors that influence the range of motion $\ce{ -> }$ shape of the articulating surfaces determines the range of movement possible [1] $\ce{ -> }$ joint capsule OR ligaments - restrict movement to prevent injury, limiting excessive range while allowing flexibility [1] $\ce{ -> }$ hinge joints only allow movement in one plane flexion AND extension [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ball and socket joints allow protraction AND retraction OR abduction AND adduction OR rotation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ range of motion is influenced by the shape and fit of the bones at the joint [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the flexibility and strength of surrounding ligaments affect how far a joint can move without injury [1] $\ce{ -> }$ damage to cartilage reduces range of movement due to pain OR friction [1] $\ce{ -> }$ stronger OR more flexible muscles can support a greater range of motion [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Synovial joints facilitate movement through their unique structure. Articulating bones are covered with cartilage to reduce friction ($\checkmark$), and synovial fluid within the joint cavity lubricates the joint ($\checkmark$). Ligaments stabilize the joint by connecting the bones ($\checkmark$), while tendons transmit forces from muscles to bones, as they are attached to both ($\checkmark$). The shape of the joint, such as ball-and-socket or hinge types, determines the types of movements possible ($\checkmark$). The range of motion is influenced by the fit of the bones ($\checkmark$), the flexibility of ligaments ($\checkmark$), and the strength of surrounding muscles ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
The table shows part of the amino acid sequence for the Haemoglobin Alpha (HBA1) gene in a number of different organisms.
OrganismAmino acid sequence for HBA1HumanAQVKGHGKKVADALSharkPSIKAHGAKVVTALDuckAQIKAHGKKVAAALBatAQVKGHGKKVGDALCobraKDIIHQGEKVGKAL
Which cladogram would best represent the relationship between these organisms, using just the information provided in the table?

A.$\hspace{1em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8eefe17a-3fc3-4141-a2bc-c5c2ed410312/images/93406774-ac02-4eb5-80a9-1d23ee939c24/BI1156A.png)

B.$\hspace{1em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8eefe17a-3fc3-4141-a2bc-c5c2ed410312/images/e55287a0-9b1d-4d8a-a71a-e3658964d3a7/cladogram%20iii.png)

C.$\hspace{1em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8eefe17a-3fc3-4141-a2bc-c5c2ed410312/images/9874311d-42b0-48a9-a4f8-f5b0646e5702/BI1156C.png)

D.$\hspace{1em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8eefe17a-3fc3-4141-a2bc-c5c2ed410312/images/a594ff10-c445-49f7-992c-9063116f1fbe/BI1156d.png)

[Â©Revision Village 2023. ]
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
First, compare the sequences of the different organisms to the human sequence:
OrganismAmino acid sequence for HBA1Number of differences from humanHumanAQVKGHGKKVADAL0 (reference)SharkPSIKAHGAKVVTAL6DuckAQIKAHGKKVAAAL3BatAQVKGHGKKVGDAL1CobraKDIIHQGEKVGKAL9
Then rank the organisms by similarity in amino acid sequences for HBA1 to humans:
Most similar is the bat, then the duck, then the shark, and then the one with the least similar sequence is the cobra
The correct cladogram is Choice D as it reflects this hierarchy.
In real life, cobra (a reptile) and human (a mammal) are both amniotes, sharing a more recent common ancestor than either does with shark, which is a cartilaginous fish. The observed pattern in the table, where the shark appears more similar to humans than the cobra based on HBA1 sequences, is an artefact of analysing a single gene and is not reflective of the broader evolutionary relationship.
Choices A, B, and C are incorrect because they do not follow the relationship order suggested by the amino acid differences in the table.

list.title: Question 28
list.content:
A  biology class was given the following information:


- I.W, X, Y and Z are all closely related animal species.II.g, W and Y all evolved from animal species X.III.Species g is an extinct recent common ancestor of W and Y.IV.Animal species Z is the least related to the others, with extinct species h serving as its most recent phylogenetic connection to the others.

Below are cladograms drawn by four different students to represent the evolutionary relationships described.
Which student drew the cladogram correctly?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/26760cb4-c948-4999-8142-62356a5904b4/images/61ddfb74-bb4b-4911-b1e2-92fbf65411c6/4%20cladograms%20together.png)

[Â©Revision Village 2024]
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Animal species  Z needs to be in a different clade to W and Y as it is the least closely related. However, Z is still linked to W and Y via animal species h. W and Y are linked via a recent common ancestor, g, and W, Y and g are all linked via animal species X. This makes student Choice B correct.
The cladogram drawn by student A is incorrect in many ways, including placing extinct species h as the most distantly related species of W and Y, and placing Z as the common ancestor connecting all the other species. Choice A  is, therefore, not the correct answer to this question.
The cladogram drawn by student C is incorrect in several places, including putting h as the most recent extinct ancestor of W and X and putting g as the common ancestor connecting all the other species. Choice C  is, therefore, not the correct answer to this question.
The cladogram drawn by student D  incorrectly groups W and X together after their divergence from the extinct species h. The cladogram incorrectly places g as the common ancestor of all the other species. Choice D  is, therefore, not the correct answer to this question.

list.title: Question 29
list.content:
The DNA sequence from the same section of DNA but from two different organisms is shown in the table below.
Which organisms are most likely to have diverged from each other most recently?

Sequence 1Sequence 2$\hspace{1em}$A.$\hspace{1em}$ATCGGGTCGCTTTCTCGATCCGGTCGCTTTGTCG$\hspace{1em}$B.$\hspace{1em}$TCGCGCGTAAATCGATGTCCCGCGTCAATCGTTA$\hspace{1em}$C.$\hspace{1em}$ATCGGGTGTGTCATATGATCGCGTGTCTCATCTG$\hspace{1em}$D.$\hspace{1em}$TGTCATCATCCCGTACTGTGTCATCATCGGCATGAC
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because the two sequences have the smallest number of differences between them, only two, therefore they are the most closely related. Choices B, C and D are incorrect, as there are more than 2 differences between the two sequences, 4, 3 and 8, respectively.

list.title: Question 30
list.content: Genetic variation is the root of phenotypic diversity between and within species. - Phenotypic expression relies on the genome and proteome. Outline the differences between the genome and the proteome [3] - While genetic variations can be beneficial, others can lead to detrimental health conditions, such as diabetes. Compare and contrast Type I and Type II diabetes. [4] - Describe the approaches used to classify different species. [8]
list.markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ genome is the complete set of genetic material present in an organism OR includes all the genes, regulatory elements and non-coding regions of the genetic material of an organism WHEREAS proteome is the entire set of proteins produced OR expressed by a cell, tissue, or organism at a specific time under defined conditions [1] $\ce{ -> }$ genome composed of DNA nucleotides WHEREAS proteome composed of amino acids [1] $\ce{ -> }$ genome stores genetic information OR is a template for the synthesis of proteome WHEREAS proteome carries out the functions of the organism OR is involved in cellular processes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ genome relatively stable over time WHEREAS proteome is highly dynamic OR proteome constantly changing in response to cellular needs OR environment OR internal signals [1] $\ce{ -> }$ size of genome is relatively constant within a species WHEREAS proteome can be much larger OR more diverse than the genome due to alternative splicing, post-translational modifications, and protein-protein interactions [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The genome is the complete set of genetic material present in an organism, including all the genes, regulatory elements and non-coding regions, whereas the proteome is the entire set of proteins produced by a cell, tissue, or organism at a specific time under defined conditions ($\checkmark$). The genome is made up of nucleotides, whereas the proteome is composed of amino acids ($\checkmark$). Functionally, the genome acts as a source of genetic instructions, providing the information necessary for development and regulation, while the proteome actively participates in cellular processes ($\checkmark$) based on these instructions. The genome is relatively stable with occasional genetic variations, whereas the proteome is highly dynamic, responding to environmental factors ($\checkmark$). - Any four of the following (AT LEAST ONE similarity and AT LEAST ONE difference must be given): $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH Types of diabetes affect blood glucose concentration OR affect the bodyâ€™s ability to control blood glucose concentration [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH types of diabetes cause health complications if blood glucose concentration is not controlled [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Type I is an autoimmune disease WHEREAS Type II is linked to genetics OR lifestyle OR ageing [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Type I diabetes is caused when the beta cells are destroyed by the immune system and do not secrete enough insulin WHEREAS Type II diabetes is caused when body cells become insensitive OR resistant to insulin [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Type I diabetes usually begins in childhood WHEREAS Type II diabetes usually begins in adulthood [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Type I diabetes cannot be controlled by lifestyle changes WHEREAS Type II diabetes can often be controlled by lifestyle changes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Type I diabetes requires frequent measurement of blood glucose concentration WHEREAS Type II diabetes does not require frequent measurement of blood glucose concentration [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Type I diabetes requires insulin injections from start WHEREAS Type II diabetes is only treated with insulin if the disease progresses [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Type I tends to be diagnosed at early age WHEREAS Type II tends to be diagnosed in older people [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Both Type I and Type II diabetes disrupt the regulation of normal blood glucose concentration ($\checkmark$). Type I diabetes is an autoimmune disease where the immune system destroys beta cells in the pancreas, resulting in a lack of insulin production. The causes of Type II diabetes are multifactorial, including genetics, lifestyle and ageing ($\checkmark$), and it manifests when body cells become resistant to insulin ($\checkmark$). Type I diabetes requires frequent measurement of blood glucose concentration, whereas Type II diabetes does not usually require frequent measurements of blood glucose concentration ($\checkmark$). Type I diabetes requires lifelong insulin injections, whereas Type II diabetes only requires insulin injections if the condition progresses ($\checkmark$). - Any eight of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ classification is used to organise organisms into groups [1] $\ce{ -> }$ binomial nomenclature OR binomial system used to name organisms OR name is genus and species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ allows communication and understanding between scientists all around the world [1] $\ce{ -> }$ there are three domains of life [1] $\ce{ -> }$ a species is the smallest unit of classification [1] $\ce{ -> }$ hierarchy is used to group species OR the taxa are arranged in order of decreasing group size: domain, kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus, species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ morphological OR artificial classification is based on physical characteristics [1] $\ce{ -> }$ morphology can lead to errors OR analogous structures can mislead classification [1] $\ce{ -> }$ biochemical classification analyses molecular components OR proteins OR DNA OR RNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ base sequences in nucleic acids OR amino acid sequences of proteins are analysed [1] $\ce{ -> }$ cladistics is based on shared characteristics traced to most recent common ancestor OR cladogram is a visual representation of how species are evolutionarily related, with a node representing a common ancestor [1] $\ce{ -> }$ modern approach combines evidence OR uses all types of classification OR uses morphology, biochemistry and genetics [1] $\ce{ -> }$ natural classification groups organisms based on evolutionary history [1] $\ce{ -> }$ classification includes fossils [1] $\ce{ -> }$ organisms with a recent common ancestor are classified more closely together [1] $\ce{ -> }$ species in the same genus share many characteristics [1] $\ce{ -> }$ organisms can be reclassified when new evidence is found [1] $\ce{ -> }$ natural classification allows scientists to predict characteristics of species within a group [1] [8 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Classification is the process of organising organisms into appropriate categories or groups based on their shared characteristics ($\checkmark$). Scientists use binomial nomenclature to assign each organism a unique two-part name made up of the genus and species ($\checkmark$), facilitating global scientific communication ($\checkmark$). Organisms are traditionally classified hierarchically, starting with the broadest category, the domain, then working downwards - kingdom, phylum, class, order, family genus, species ($\checkmark$) (which can then be split into sub-species). Traditional, artificial, classification has been based on physical traits. However, this morphological approach ($\checkmark$) can be misleading due to analogous structures ($\checkmark$). Modern classification integrates morphological, biochemical, and genetic information, ($\checkmark$). Biochemical classification examines the molecular components of organisms, including the sequences of bases of DNA and amino acids of proteins ($\checkmark$). Cladistics is based on shared characteristics traced to the most recent common ancestor, and these relationships can be represented visually on cladograms ($\checkmark$). As new data emerges, reclassification may occur ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

list.title: Question 31
list.content: The diagrams below show two cladograms for primates. One cladogram was made using data from DNA sequences and the other using amino acid sequences. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d834264a-48ae-474c-af53-c7ed003a94e8/images/d839b234-e401-4a51-ae04-32fd9b023985/BI0272.png) [Source: Adapted from Bockman, P. (2011, October 3). File: Primate cladogram.jpg. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 14, 2022, from https: //commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Primate_cladogram.jpg CC-BY-SA-3.0] - Identify the organism(s) most closely related to humans in the cladogram based onâ€¦ - DNA sequences [1] - amino acid sequences [1] - Describe the advantage of using DNA sequences to construct cladograms compared to amino acid sequences. [2] - Suggest why cladograms made using physical features are not reliable predictors of phylogenetic relationships. [2]
list.markScheme: - - $\ce{ -> }$ apes [1] [1 mark maximum] - $\ce{ -> }$ old world monkeys AND new world monkeys [1] [1 mark maximum] - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ the nucleotide sequence of a gene contains more information than the amino acid sequence of the corresponding polypeptides [1] $\ce{ -> }$ silent mutations alter the DNA sequence but do not affect the amino acid sequence [1] $\ce{ -> }$ degeneracy in the genetic code means a mutation does not necessarily change the amino acid sequence [1] $\ce{ -> }$ greater information can be obtained by DNA sequence analysis because variability in both the coding and non-coding regions of the genome can be examined [1] $\ce{ -> }$ DNA samples can be easily sequenced OR DNA is cheaper to sequence OR DNA sequencing yields more data whereas the approach to sequencing of proteins varies with type of protein [1] $\ce{ -> }$ DNA sequence can be used to establish amino acid sequence, but not the other way around [1] [2 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Using DNA sequences to construct cladograms is advantageous because due to the existence of coding and non-coding regions ($\checkmark$) of DNA, more information ($\checkmark$) is held in the nucleotide sequence than the amino acid sequence . Also mutations may occur in the DNA which do not show up in the amino acid sequence due to the degenerative code ($\checkmark$) leading to silent mutations ($\checkmark$). - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ adaptive radiation can result in closely related species showing very different structural features [1] $\ce{ -> }$ convergent evolution means that distantly related organisms may show very similar structural features [1] $\ce{ -> }$ analogous structures are derived through separate evolutionary pathways and are not indicators of evolutionary relationships [1] $\ce{ -> }$ DNA and amino acid analysis have shown that some classification of organisms based on shared structural features was incorrect [1] [2 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Cladograms are no longer based on structural features due to the presence of analogous structures, which are the result of convergent evolution ($\checkmark$) and so are not indicators of evolutionary relationships ($\checkmark$). DNA and amino acid analysis have shown that many cladograms based solely on shared structural features are incorrect ($\checkmark$).

list.title: Question 32
list.content:
Which feature of Archaea helped biologists to classify them in a separate domain from other prokaryotes?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ The presence of a cell wall
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ The frequency of introns in the genome
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ The presence of linear chromosomes
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ The difference in structure of membrane phospholipids
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The rRNA sequencing by Carl Woese (1977) revealed that Eubacteria and Archaea are fundamentally different at a molecular level, including differences in membrane lipid structure.
Archaea have membrane phospholipids consisting of the L-glycerol in the phosphate group. Eubacteria, and Eukarya, have D-glycerol in the phosphate groups of their phospholipids. Choice D is, therefore, correct.
Choice A is incorrect because cell walls are present in both domains (Archaea and Eubacteria), although made of different polymers.
Choice B  is incorrect because introns (non-coding regions of DNA) are found in Eukaryota only, not in either of the prokaryote domains.
Choice C is incorrect because linear chromosomes are found in Eukaryota only, not in either of the prokaryote domains. The genomes of Archaea and Eubacteria are made of circular DNA.

list.title: Question 33
list.content:
Organisms may be reclassified using evidence from cladistics. Cladogram 1, based on DNA comparisons of several species, represents the historical view of relationships among arachnids. Cladogram 2, based on DNA comparisons of many more species than Cladogram 1, challenges the historical view.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9f58f8ff-0c6d-45ec-b83b-b630124d062a/images/facf56c0-5f41-4a9d-9e82-077c9b0d142f/BI0510.png)


[Source: Adapted from Ballesteros, J.A., SantibÃ¡Ã±ez-LÃ³pez, C.E., Baker, C.M.,  Benavides, L.R., Cunha T.J., Gainett, G., Ontano A.Z., Setton, E.V.W, Arango, C.P., Gavish-Regev, E., Harvey, M.S., Wheeler, W.C., Hormiga, G., Giribet, G., & Sharma, P.P. (2022). Comprehensive Species Sampling and Sophisticated Algorithmic Approaches Refute the Monophyly of Arachnida. Molecular Biology and Evolution, Volume 39, Issue 2, Retrieved March 15, 2022, from https://doi.org/10.1093/molbev/msac021. Copyright under CC BY 4.0]
What is suggested by Cladogram 2 that is not suggested by Cladogram 1?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Horseshoe crabs are a sister group of arachnids.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Horseshoe crabs are a group within arachnids.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Sea spiders are an ancestor of arachnids.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Sea spiders are not an ancestor of horseshoe crabs.
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Both cladograms show the relationships among arachnids and organisms related to arachnids. Cladogram 1 shows sea spiders and horseshoe crabs as related to, but not members, of the arachnids. Horseshoe crabs therefore form a sister group to the arachnids (A sister group is the closest relative to a given unit in a cladogram). Cladogram 2 shows horseshoe crabs as a group within the arachnids.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9f58f8ff-0c6d-45ec-b83b-b630124d062a/images/fc803d09-abaa-4f4e-bdb8-31f8b7aab5c1/BI0510A.png)


So, Cladogram 2 indicates that horseshoe crabs are a group within the arachnids, a relationship not indicated by Cladogram 1.
Cladogram 1, not Cladogram 2, indicates that horseshoe crabs are a sister group of arachnids (Choice A). Both cladograms show that sea spiders were an ancestor of arachnids (Choices C and D).

list.title: Question 34
list.content: - Natural classification is used to group organisms with common ancestry together, based on similarities and shared characteristics. All organisms can be classified into one of the three domains. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dec0eb78-75d9-46b9-8d5b-dd3556815829/images/5ca392ca-aa33-406f-ace3-eb2621e12545/BI0260.png) [ Â© Revision Village 2022] - List three characteristics of Eubacteria. [3] - Distinguish between archaeans and eukaryotes. [1] - Outline how a case study like the reclassification of the figwort family (Scrophulariaceae) demonstrates the limitations of morphology-based taxonomy.[4]
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because Eukaryota are the only group with nuclei and membrane-bound organelles. Choice B and choice C are incorrect because organisms in these two domains (Archaea and Eubacteria) do not have membrane-enclosed organelles. Choice D is incorrect because prokaryotes are not the name of a domain.
